'''Chromebook''' (sometimes stylized in lowercase as '''chromebook''') is a line of [[laptop]] and [[Tablet computer|tablet computers]] that runs using [[ChromeOS]], an operating system developed by [[Google]].

Chromebook runs [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Linux]], and [[Progressive web app|Progressive web apps]], as well as functioning offline.<ref>{{cite web |last=Tofel |first=Kevin C. |date=June 5, 2014 |title=Grab the remote: Chromebooks can now watch Play Movies, TV shows offline |url=https://involvematrix.com/best-chromebooks-2024-top-5-best-chromebooks-in-2024/ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211029001933/https://gigaom.com/2014/06/05/grab-the-remote-chromebooks-can-now-watch-movies-tv-offline/ |archive-date=October 29, 2021 |access-date=June 6, 2014 |work=Gigaom}}</ref> They are manufactured and offered by various [[OEM]]s,<ref>{{Cite web |title=What's with all the Chromebooks? |url=https://involvematrix.com/best-chromebooks-2024-top-5-best-chromebooks-in-2024/ |access-date=2023-10-25 |website=PCWorld |language=en}}</ref> and, in addition to the laptop and tablet form factors, they are available as [[Chromebox|desktops]], [[All-in-one computer|all-in-ones]], and previously as an [[HDMI]] [[stick PC]].

The first Chromebooks shipped on June 15, 2011. As of 2020, Chromebook's market share is 10.8%, placing it above the [[Mac (computer)|Mac]] platform; it has mainly found success in education markets.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2021-02-18 |title=Chromebooks overtake Macs in market share for first time |language=en-GB |work=BBC News |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-56116573 |access-date=2023-10-25}}</ref>

== History ==
The first Chromebooks for sale, by [[Acer Inc.]] and [[Samsung]], were announced at the [[Google I/O]] conference in May 2011 and began shipping on June 15, 2011.<ref name="Google blog ann">{{cite web |last1=Upson |first1=Linus |last2=Pichai |first2=Sundar |date=May 11, 2011 |title=A New Kind Of Computer: Chromebook |url=https://googleblog.blogspot.com/2011/05/new-kind-of-computer-chromebook.html?+ |access-date=May 12, 2011 |work=The Official Google Blog}}</ref> [[Lenovo]], [[Hewlett-Packard]] (now [[HP Inc.]]) and [[Google]] itself entered the market in early 2013. In December 2013, Samsung launched a Samsung Chromebook specifically for the Indian market that employed the company's [[Exynos]] 5 Dual core processor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gadgetcluster.com/samsung-chromebook-launched-in-india-for-rs-26990/ |title=Samsung Chromebook launched in India for Rs.26990 |publisher=Gadget Cluster |date=December 5, 2013 |access-date=December 9, 2013 |archive-date=December 9, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131209040706/http://www.gadgetcluster.com/samsung-chromebook-launched-in-india-for-rs-26990/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>

Critical reaction to the device was initially skeptical, with some reviewers, such as then ''New York Times'' technology columnist [[David Pogue]],<ref name="Pogue Chromebook pt1" /> unfavorably comparing the [[value proposition]] of Chromebooks with that of more fully featured laptops running the Microsoft Windows operating system. That complaint dissipated later in reviews of machines from Acer and Samsung that were priced lower.<ref name="Pogue:Chromebook pt2" />

In February 2013, Google announced and began shipping the [[Chromebook Pixel]], a higher-spec machine with a high-end retail price.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/2/21/4013480/google-chromebook-pixel|title=Google announces Chromebook Pixel: a premium Chrome OS laptop shipping next week for $1,299|last=Hollister|first=Sean|date=February 21, 2013|work=The Verge|access-date=May 3, 2018}}</ref>

In January 2015, Acer announced the first big screen Chromebook, the Acer Chromebook 15 with an [[FHD]] 15.6-inch display.<ref name="acer15">{{cite web|last1=Purcell|first1=Kevin|title=Acer Chromebook 15: Finally a Big Screen Chromebook|url=http://notebooks.com/2015/01/05/acer-chromebook-15-finally-a-big-screen-chromebook/|website=notebooks.com|access-date=September 5, 2017|date=January 5, 2015}}</ref>

By March 2018, Chromebooks made up 60% of computers purchased by schools in the United States. In October 2012, Simon Phipps, writing in ''[[InfoWorld]]'', said, "The Chromebook line is probably the most successful Linux desktop/laptop computer we've seen to date".<ref name="Phipps26Oct12">{{cite news|last=Phipps|first=Simon|date=October 26, 2012|title=Why I left my MacBook for a Chromebook|work=[[InfoWorld]]|url=http://www.infoworld.com/d/open-source-software/why-i-left-my-macbook-chromebook-205705|access-date=October 28, 2012}}</ref>

On October 9, 2023, Google announced Chromebook Plus, a new category of Chromebooks that included faster CPUs (Intel Core i3 12th Gen or the AMD Ryzen 3 7000 series), at least 8GB of RAM, 1080p IPS or better display and a 1080p+ web camera. These support video-editing by LumaFusion and web versions of Google Photos Magic Eraser and Adobe Photoshop.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-10-02 |title=Chromebook Plus: more performance and AI capabilities |url=https://blog.google/products/chromebooks/chromebook-plus/ |access-date=2023-12-19 |website=Google |language=en-us}}</ref> 

=== Other form factors ===
Chromebooks are available from OEMs in various form factors, some form factors may be known by other names: 

*Chromebook in laptop form factor.
*Chromebook tablet, introduced in March 2018 by Acer, the Chromebook Tab 10. The device was to compete with the lower-priced Apple iPad tablet in the education market.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Kastrenakes |first=Jacob |date=March 26, 2018 |title=The first Chrome OS tablet is here {{!}} The Verge |url=https://www.theverge.com/platform/amp/circuitbreaker/2018/3/26/17157444/acer-chromebook-tab-10-first-chrome-os-tablet-announced |access-date=March 27, 2018 |website=www.theverge.com |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Amadeo |first=Ron |date=March 26, 2018 |title=Chrome OS tablets are official—Meet the Acer Chromebook Tab 10 |work=Ars Technica |url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2018/03/chrome-os-tablets-are-official-meet-the-acer-chromebook-tab-10/ |access-date=March 27, 2018}}</ref>
*[[Chromebox]], a [[Nettop|small form-factor PC]] first introduced by [[Samsung]] in May 2012.<ref name="kelion2012">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-18253961|title=Google Chrome OS computers updated with faster processors|date=May 29, 2012|author=Leo Kelion|work=BBC News}}</ref>
*Chromebase, an [[Desktop computer#All-in-one|all-in-one]] desktop PC was introduced by [[LG Electronics]] in January 2014.
*[[Chromebit]], an HDMI [[stick PC]] introduced by [[Asus]] in April 2015. However, as of 2019 OEMs do not currently manufacture these.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Auto Update policy - Google Chrome Enterprise Help |url=https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/6220366?hl=en |access-date=April 27, 2020 |website=support.google.com}}</ref>

=== Integration with Android ===
In May 2016, Google announced it would make Android apps available on Chromebooks via the [[Google Play]] application distribution platform. At the time, Google Play access was scheduled for the ASUS Chromebook Flip, the Acer Chromebook R 11 and the most recent Chromebook Pixel, with other Chromebooks slated over time.<ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.businessinsider.com/google-chromebook-android-apps-chrome-os-support-list-2017-1 |title=Google says every new Chromebook will work with Android apps from here on out |work=Business Insider |access-date=August 17, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.blog.google/products/chromebooks/the-google-play-store-coming-to/|title=The Google Play store, coming to a Chromebook near you|date=May 19, 2016|newspaper=Google}}</ref><ref name="wired2016">{{cite magazine|last1=Pierce|first1=David|title=How Chromebooks Are About to Totally Transform Laptop Design|url=https://www.wired.com/2016/09/chromebooks-totally-transform-laptop-design/|magazine=Wired|access-date=September 5, 2017|date=September 9, 2016|quote=Windows manufacturers have been experimenting with convertible and detachable devices for the last few years, but the combination of Android and Chrome will actually make them work. ... they'll work the way people do in 2016: online everywhere, all the time, in a thousand different ways.}}</ref> Partnering with Google, Samsung released the Chromebook Plus and Chromebook Pro in early 2017, the first Chromebooks to come with the Play Store pre-installed.<ref>{{Cite news |url= http://www.businessinsider.com/samsung-chromebook-pro-plus-google-android-specs-features-photos-2017-1 |title=Samsung and Google teamed up to make two new Chromebooks that run Android apps |work=Business Insider |access-date=August 17, 2017}}</ref> A February 2017 review in ''The Verge'' reported that the Plus with its [[ARM architecture|ARM]] processor handled Android apps "much better" than the [[Intel]]-based Pro, but said that "Android apps on Chrome OS are still in beta" and are "very much [an] unfinished experience."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/2/10/14570480/samsung-chromebook-plus-laptop-review|title=Samsung Chromebook Plus review: the best Chrome OS laptop, for now|last=Bohn|first=Dieter|date=February 10, 2017|website=The Verge|access-date=August 17, 2017}}</ref> The number of ChromeOS systems supporting Android apps in either the stable or beta channel is increasing.<ref name="AndroidSupport">{{cite web|title=Chrome OS Systems Supporting Android Apps|url=https://www.chromium.org/chromium-os/chrome-os-systems-supporting-android-apps|website=The Chromium Projects|access-date=September 5, 2017|quote=The Chromebooks, Chromeboxes, and Chromebases that will be able to install Android apps are listed below. Roll-out of Android Apps is done on a device-per-device basis as it is dependent on a number of factors including the hardware platform that the device is based on and each device must be compatible with Android. While we won't be able to bring Android apps to every Chromebook ever made, we're continuing to evaluate more devices and we'll update this list as new devices are added.}}</ref><ref name="AndroidChrome">{{cite web|last1=Raphael|first1=JR|title=Google's turning on the gas on its Android-Chrome OS alignment|url=https://www.computerworld.com/article/3214404/mobile-wireless/android-chrome-os-alignment.html|website=computerworld.com|access-date=September 5, 2017|date=August 8, 2017}}</ref>

In the 2021 Android 11 launch, it was announced that Android apps would be moved to a new virtual machine called ArcVM, to improve Android’s environment isolation for better security and maintainability.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Jorgensen |first=Mark |date=2024-01-04 |title=Google Chrome OS 100 is On Its Way to Chromebooks! |url=https://ctl.net/blogs/insights/google-chrome-os-100-is-on-its-way-to-chromebooks |access-date=2024-01-04 |website=CRL.Net}}</ref>

=== Compatibility with Linux applications (GNU compatibility) ===
In May 2018, Google announced it would make Linux desktop applications available on Chromebooks via a [[virtual machine]] code-named "Crostini". ChromeOS, which runs on Chromebooks, is already based on the Linux kernel, but it does not provide default support for applications that expect a GNU-based system. Crostini left the beta stage in May 2021 as part of release 91.<ref>{{Cite web |url= https://www.blog.google/products/chromebooks/linux-on-chromebooks/ |title=Chromebooks are ready for your next coding project |date=May 8, 2018 |work=Google Blog |access-date=October 17, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/5/20/22445382/chromeos-linux-release-beta-version-91|title=Chrome OS's Linux app support is leaving beta |first=Jon|last=Porter|date=May 20, 2021|website=The Verge}}</ref> Google maintains a list of devices that were launched before 2019, which support Crostini.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Lima|first=Carlos|date=August 2, 2021|title=How to install Linux apps on your Chromebook|url=https://www.laptopmag.com/au/how-to/install-linux-apps-on-your-chromebook|url-status=live|access-date=August 16, 2021|website=Laptop Mag|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210816054718/https://www.laptopmag.com/au/how-to/install-linux-apps-on-your-chromebook |archive-date=August 16, 2021 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Chrome OS Systems Supporting Linux (Beta)|url=https://sites.google.com/a/chromium.org/dev/chromium-os/chrome-os-systems-supporting-linux|url-status=live|access-date=August 16, 2021|website=Google - The Chromium Projects|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200612064239/https://sites.google.com/a/chromium.org/dev/chromium-os/chrome-os-systems-supporting-linux |archive-date=June 12, 2020 }}</ref>

== Design ==
[[File:Samsung Chromebook Series 3 internals.JPG|thumb|Samsung Chromebook Series 3 with bottom panel removed]]

Initial hardware partners for Chromebook development included [[Acer Inc.|Acer]], [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]], [[Asus]], [[Freescale]], [[Hewlett-Packard]] (later [[HP Inc.]]), [[Lenovo]], [[Qualcomm]], [[Texas Instruments]], [[Toshiba]],<ref>{{cite web|url= http://chrome.blogspot.com/2009/07/google-chrome-os-faq.html |title=Google Chrome OS FAQ |last= Pichai |first= Sundar |date= July 8, 2009 |work= Official Google Blog |publisher= Google, Inc.|access-date= July 21, 2009}}</ref> [[Intel]],<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.osnews.com/story/21812 |title=Intel Cozying up to Google Chrome OS|last= Myslewski |first= Rik |date= July 10, 2009 |work= The RegisterOSnews |access-date= July 11, 2012}}</ref> [[Samsung]],<ref name="Channel News Aust">{{cite web|url= http://www.channelnews.com.au/Hardware/Mobility/T3H4L5C6 |title= Samsung Confirms Chrome Based Netbook|last= Richards |first= David |date=February 11, 2010|work= Channel News Australia |access-date= February 13, 2010 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130302061113/http://www.channelnews.com.au/Hardware/Mobility/T3H4L5C6 |archive-date= March 2, 2013}}</ref><ref name="engadget">{{cite web|url= https://www.engadget.com/2010/12/07/google-chrome-os-gets-detailed/ |title= Google Chrome OS gets detailed, first laptops from Acer and Samsung coming mid-2011|date=December 7, 2010 |work=engadget |access-date=December 11, 2010}}</ref> and [[Dell Inc.|Dell]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Dell Tests Google's Chrome Operating System on Some Computers |url= https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-06-25/dell-tests-google-s-chrome-operating-system-on-netbook-tablet-computers.html |access-date=September 5, 2010 |work=Bloomberg News |date=June 25, 2010 |last=Ricadela |first=Aaron}}</ref>

Chromebooks ship with [[ChromeOS]], an operating system that uses the [[Linux kernel]] and the Google Chrome web browser with an integrated media-player.<ref name="CT10May11">{{cite news|url= http://www.conceivablytech.com/7296/products/chrome-os-file-manager-gets-secret-shortcuts |title= Chrome OS File Manager Gets Secret Shortcuts |access-date= May 15, 2011 |last= Bailey |first= Dan |date= May 2011 |work= Conceivably Tech |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120801070205/http://www.conceivablytech.com/7296/products/chrome-os-file-manager-gets-secret-shortcuts |archive-date= August 1, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last= Smith |first= William |title= 8 Things You Need to Know About Chrome OS |newspaper= Pcgamer |url= http://www.maximumpc.com/article/features/8_things_you_need_know_about_chrome_os |publisher= MaximumPC|access-date= May 14, 2011}}</ref> Enabling developer mode allows the installation of [[Linux distribution]]s and other operating systems on Chromebooks. Chromebooks also include a screw or switch directly on the motherboard to enable or disable write protection. [[chroot|Crouton]] is a script that allows the installation of Linux distributions from ChromeOS and running both operating systems simultaneously.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.networkworld.com/article/934288/3-ways-to-run-normal-linux-on-a-chromebook.html |title=3 ways to run 'normal' Linux on a Chromebook|author=Bryan Lunduke|date=January 12, 2015|work=Network World}}</ref> Some Chromebooks include [[SeaBIOS]], which can be enabled to install and boot Linux distributions directly.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://gigaom.com/2013/02/26/3-alternatives-to-chrome-os-on-googles-chromebook-pixel/ |title=3 alternatives to Chrome OS on Google's Chromebook Pixel — Tech News and Analysis |publisher=Gigaom.com |date=February 26, 2013 |access-date=February 25, 2014 |archive-date=March 11, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140311012155/http://gigaom.com/2013/02/26/3-alternatives-to-chrome-os-on-googles-chromebook-pixel/ |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=article&item=acer_c720_linux|title=Acer C720 Chromebook Delivers Fast Ubuntu Performance Review - Phoronix|website=www.phoronix.com}}</ref> With limited offline capability and a fast boot-time, Chromebooks are primarily designed for use while connected to the Internet<ref name="WSJ: Google to Launch">{{cite news |last2=Sherr |first2=Ian |first1=Amir |last1=Efrati |title=Google Sets Laptop Foray |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703730804576317361801753874 |access-date=May 11, 2011 |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |location=New York |date=May 11, 2011}}</ref> and signed in to a Google account.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.pcworld.com/article/2860459/computers/how-to-set-up-your-new-chromebook-the-right-way.html|title=How to set up your new Chromebook the right way |last=Walter |first=Derek |date=February 16, 2017 |work=PCWorld |access-date=December 5, 2017}}</ref> Instead of installing [[application software|traditional applications]] that propose risk of malware, users install [[web application|web apps]] from the [[Chrome Web Store]].<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.google.com/support/chrome_webstore/bin/answer.py?hl=en-GB&answer=1047776&ctx=cbo/ |title=What is the Chrome Web Store? |publisher= [[Google Inc.]]}}</ref> Google claims that a multi-layer security architecture eliminates the need for anti-virus software.<ref name="Google blog ann" />

Support for many Bluetooth and USB devices such as cameras, mice, external keyboards and flash drives is included, utilizing a feature similar to [[plug-and-play]] on other operating systems.

All Chromebooks, except the first three, boot with the help of [[Coreboot]], a fast booting [[BIOS]].<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.phoronix.com/scan.php?page=news_item&px=MTA5MDk |title= Many FSF Priority Projects Still Not Progressing |date= April 22, 2012 |access-date= December 29, 2014 |quote= The success out of Coreboot recently is Google providing Sandy/Ivy Bridge support for Coreboot. Google's planning to begin shipping new Intel 'Chromebooks' that will use Coreboot. Google likes Coreboot for the faster start-up time, among other benefits. |first= Michael |last= Larabel |author-link= Michael Larabel |publisher= [[Phoronix]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.coreboot.org/Chromebooks |title= Chromebooks |format= [[MediaWiki]] |website= www.coreboot.org |access-date= September 22, 2016 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160508225442/https://www.coreboot.org/Chromebooks |archive-date= May 8, 2016 |url-status= dead }}</ref>

Google supports new Chromebooks made since 2021 with automatic updates for at least 10 years. Previously, Chromebooks were supported 8 years, while they were initially supported for 6.5 years.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Chin |first=Monica |date=2023-09-15 |title=Chromebooks will soon get 10 years of automatic updates |url=https://www.theverge.com/2023/9/14/23873319/google-chromebook-chrome-os-automatic-security-updates |access-date=2024-01-04 |website=The Verge}}</ref> The date when a device will stop receiving automatic software and security updates can be found in the "Additional info" section of the "About device" in the device settings.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Gavin |first=Brady |date=January 6, 2020 |title=How to See Your Chromebook's End-of-Life Date |url= https://www.howtogeek.com/467095/how-to-see-your-chromebooks-end-of-life-date/ |url-status=live |access-date=August 12, 2021 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20200108022308/https://www.howtogeek.com/467095/how-to-see-your-chromebooks-end-of-life-date/ |archive-date=January 8, 2020 }}</ref> Google maintain an Auto Update policy listing ChromeOS makes and models with their auto update expiration dates.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Auto Update policy |url= https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/6220366 |url-status=live |access-date=August 12, 2021|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20151118223430/https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/6220366 |archive-date=November 18, 2015 }}</ref>

== Sales and marketing ==
[[File:ChromebookStaplesStore.jpg|thumb|Chromebooks at a Staples retail store]]
The first two commercially available Chromebooks, the [[Samsung]] Series 5 and the [[Acer Inc.|Acer]] AC700, were unveiled on May 11, 2011, at the [[Google I/O]] developer conference. They were to begin selling through online channels, including [[Amazon (company)|Amazon]] and [[Best Buy]] in the United States, the United Kingdom, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Italy and Spain starting June 15, 2011; however, Acer's AC700 was not available until early July.<ref>{{cite web |author=Melanie Pinola |url=http://news.idg.no/cw/art.cfm?id=067298FC-1A64-67EA-E4FA60A653125420 |title=Acer ships AC700 Chromebook |date=July 11, 2011 |access-date=January 1, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140102194502/http://news.idg.no/cw/art.cfm?id=067298FC-1A64-67EA-E4FA60A653125420 |archive-date=January 2, 2014 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The first machines sold for between $349 and $499, depending on the model and 3G option.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/05/11/the-google-chrome-netbook-breaks-cover-at-io-2011/ |title=The Google Chromebook Breaks Cover At I/O 2011, Hits Retailers June 15th |work=[[TechCrunch]] |date=May 11, 2011 }}</ref> Google also offered a monthly payment scheme for business and education customers at $28 and $20 per user, per month, respectively for a three-year contract, including replacements and upgrades. [[Verizon]] offers models equipped with [[3G]]/[[LTE (telecommunication)|4G LTE]] connectivity 100–200 MB of free wireless data per month, for two years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.samsung.com/us/news/newsRead.do?news_seq=20179 |title=Samsung |publisher=Samsung |date=May 29, 2012 |access-date=October 3, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=HP |url=http://www8.hp.com/us/en/hp-news/press-release.html?id=1485855 |title=HP News – HP Unveils Sleek and Colorful Chromebook |publisher=hp.com |date=September 11, 2013 |access-date=October 3, 2013}}</ref>

Google's early marketing efforts relied primarily on hands-on experience: giving away Samsung machines to 10 Cr-48 pilot program participants along with the title Chromebook Guru and lending Chromebooks to passengers on some [[Virgin America]] flights.<ref name="Sood24Jun11">{{cite news|url = http://www.gadgetell.com/technologytell/article/google-launches-new-chromebook-guru-program/|title = Google launches new Chromebook Guru Program|access-date = August 11, 2011|last = Sood|first = Natesh|date = June 2011|work = Gagetell|archive-date = October 1, 2011|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111001025819/http://www.gadgetell.com/technologytell/article/google-launches-new-chromebook-guru-program/|url-status = dead}}</ref><ref name="Parfeni23Jun11">{{cite news|url = http://news.softpedia.com/news/The-Most-Enthusiastic-Cr-48-Owners-Will-Get-a-Free-Samsung-Chromebook-207840.shtml|title = The Most Enthusiastic Cr-48 Owners Will Get a Free Samsung Chromebook|access-date = August 11, 2011|last = Parfeni|first = Lucien|date=June 2011| work = [[Softpedia]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Paula|first=Rooney|title=Google, Virgin America partner to push ChromeBooks, free WiFi in the clouds (the real ones)|url=http://www.zdnet.com/blog/open-source/google-virgin-america-partner-to-push-chromebooks-free-wifi-in-the-clouds-the-real-ones/9188|access-date=July 2, 2011|newspaper=ZDNet|date=June 30, 2011}}</ref>

=== Education market ===
[[File:PVUSD student using GoogleApps.jpg|thumb|A [[Paradise Valley Unified School District]] student using a Chromebook as part of the organization's pilot project]]
The education market has been the Chromebooks' most notable success, competing on the low cost of the hardware, software and upkeep. The simplicity of the machines, which could be a drawback in other markets, has proven an advantage to school districts by reducing training and maintenance costs.<ref name=":1" />

By January 2012, even while commercial sales were flat, Google placed nearly 27,000 Chromebooks in schools across 41 states in the US, including "one-on-one" programs, which allocate a computer for every student in South Carolina, Illinois, and Iowa.<ref name="ChronSchools">{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2012/01/25/BUF61MTEAP.DTL&tsp=1|title=Google's Chromebooks making big school push|last=Temple|first=James|date=January 25, 2012|access-date=February 6, 2012|newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle}}</ref> As of August 2012, over 500 school districts in the United States and Europe were using the device.<ref name="ZDNet">{{cite news|url=http://www.zdnet.com/the-google-chromebook-suddenly-is-an-enterprise-contender-7000006018/|title=The Google Chromebook, Suddenly, Is An Enterprise Contender|last=Lai|first=Eric|date=October 21, 2012|access-date=October 11, 2012|newspaper=ZDNet}}</ref><ref name="TechCrunch 500 Schools">{{cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/06/25/chromebooks-education-500-school-districts/|title=Google: More Than 500 School Districts In The U.S. And Europe Now Use Chromebooks|last=Lardinois|first=Frederic|date=June 25, 2012|access-date=October 22, 2012|newspaper=Techcrunch}}</ref> In 2016, Chromebooks represented 58 percent of the 2.6 million mobile devices purchased by U.S. schools and about 64 percent of that market outside the U.S. By contrast, sales of Apple devices to U.S. schools dropped that year to 19 percent, compared with 52 percent in 2012.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/02/technology/microsoft-google-educational-sales.html |title=Microsoft Looks to Regain Lost Ground in the Classroom |last1=Wingfield |first1=Nick |date=May 2, 2017 |work=The New York Times|access-date=May 6, 2017 |last2=Singer |first2=Natasha}}</ref>

Helping spur Chromebook sales is [[Google Classroom]], an app designed for teachers in 2014, that serves as a hub for classroom activities including attendance, classroom discussions, homework and communication with students and parents.<ref name=":1" />

There have, however, been [[Privacy concerns regarding Google|concerns]] about privacy within the context of the education market for Chromebooks. ==== Long term cost issues ====
Chromebooks were popular with educational institutions due to its low initial price. This is offset by the short [[Product lifetime|lifetime]] of the product, which is built-in, meaning it cannot be repurposed as well as other computers can at the end of its service life and has very little resell value. Schools usually also need to pay for software subscriptions because fewer apps come bundled with Chromebooks compared to other laptops.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Nguyen |first=Nicole |title=Chromebooks Were Once a Good Deal for Schools. Now They're Becoming E-Waste. |url=https://www.wsj.com/tech/chromebooks-were-once-a-good-deal-for-schools-now-theyre-becoming-e-waste-dc93833b |access-date=2023-11-08 |website=WSJ |language=en-US}}</ref>

At a December 7, 2010, press briefing,<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uQzAUaZ26co#t=1h16m3s | archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211111/uQzAUaZ26co| archive-date=November 11, 2021 | url-status=live|title=Chrome Event – 12/07/2010 |work=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Upson |first=Linus |url= http://chrome.blogspot.com/2010/12/update-on-chrome-web-store-and-chrome.html | title=Google Chrome Blog: An update on Chrome, the Web Store and Chrome OS |publisher= Chrome.blogspot.com |date=December 7, 2010 |access-date =February 2, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.google.com/chromeos/pilot-program.html |title= Cr48 – Pilot-Program – Chrome OS |date=December 8, 2010 |access-date=February 2, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101208144828/https://www.google.com/chromeos/pilot-program.html |archive-date=December 8, 2010 }}</ref> Google announced the ChromeOS Pilot Program, a [[pilot experiment]] and the first Chromebook, the Cr-48 Chrome Notebook, a [[prototype]], to test the ChromeOS operating system and modified hardware for it. The device had a minimal design and was all black, completely unbranded although it was made by [[Inventec]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Savov |first=Vlad |url=https://www.engadget.com/2010/12/08/inventec-ships-60-000-chrome-os-netbooks-to-google-says-let-the/ |title=Inventec ships 60,000 Chrome OS netbooks to Google, says 'let the testing begin!' |date=December 8, 2010 |publisher=Engadget.com |access-date=February 18, 2014}}</ref> and had a rubberized coating. The device was named after [[Isotopes of chromium|Chromium-48]], an [[unstable isotope]] of the metallic element Chromium (chemical symbol '''Cr'''),<ref name="Metz14Dec10">{{cite news |url = https://www.theregister.co.uk/2010/12/14/google_chrome_os_cr_48/ |title = Google Cr-48: Inside the Chrome OS 'unstable isotope' |access-date =January 4, 2012 |last = Metz |first = Cade |date = December 10, 2010 |newspaper=[[The Register]]}}</ref> and the participants were named Cr-48 Test Pilots. Google distributed about 60,000 Cr-48 Chrome Notebooks between December 2010 and March 2011<ref name="Paul15Dec10">{{cite news |url = https://arstechnica.com/open-source/reviews/2010/12/nothing-but-net-hands-on-test-of-the-cr-48-chrome-os-laptop.ars |title = Nothing but 'Net: hands-on with the Cr-48 Chrome OS laptop |access-date =December 16, 2010 |last = Paul |first = Ryan |date=December 2010 | work=[[Ars Technica]]}}</ref><ref name="Gruener15Dec10">{{cite news |url = http://www.conceivablytech.com/4624/products/chrome-os-is-ahead-of-its-time/ |title = Chrome OS Is Ahead Of Its Time |access-date =December 14, 2010 |last = Gruener |first = Wolfgang |date=December 2010 | work=Conceivably Tech |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120306141346/http://www.conceivablytech.com/4624/products/chrome-os-is-ahead-of-its-time |archive-date = March 6, 2012}}</ref> for free to participants and in return asked for feedback such as suggestions and bug reports. The Cr-48 was intended for testing only, not retail sales.<ref name="CNET hardware pilot">{{cite news |last=Ackerman |first=Dan |title=Google Cr-48 Chrome hardware pilot program: "Not for the faint of heart" |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20024897-1.html |access-date=December 8, 2010 |newspaper=[[CNET News]] |date=December 7, 2010 |archive-date=November 3, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103183334/http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20024897-1.html |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref name="Wired09Dec10">{{cite magazine |url = https://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2010/12/cr-48-chrome-os-first-look/?pid=888&viewall=true |title = First Look: Google's Netbook Has Its Head in the Cloud |access-date =December 10, 2010 |last = Calore |first = Michael |date=December 2010 | magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]}}</ref><ref name="GoogleCR48Home">{{cite web |url= https://www.google.com/chromeos/pilot-program-cr48.html |title=Cr-48 Chrome Notebook |access-date =December 13, 2010 |date=December 2010}}</ref>

The Cr-48's hardware design broke convention by replacing certain keys with shortcut keys,<ref>{{cite web|author=Chromebook |url=https://support.google.com/chromebook/answer/188743 |title=Explore keyboard features – Chromebook Help |publisher=Google Inc. |access-date=February 18, 2014}}</ref> such as the function keys, and replacing the caps lock key with a dedicated search key (now called the "Everything Button"),<ref>{{cite web |url=https://gizmodo.com/5708638/ |title=Google wants to take your Caps Lock key away |publisher=[[Gizmodo]] |first=Jesus |last=Diaz |date=December 7, 2010 |access-date=December 7, 2010}}</ref> which can be changed back to caps lock in the OS's keyboard settings. Google addressed complaints that the operating system offers little functionality when the host device is not connected to the Internet, demonstrated an offline version of [[Google Docs]], and announced a [[3G]] plan that would give users 100 MB of free data each month, with additional paid plans available from Verizon.<ref name="WSJ: Google to Launch" /><ref name="Paul08Dec10">{{cite news|url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/guides/2010/12/google-demos-chrome-os-launches-pilot-program.ars|title=Google demos Chrome OS, launches pilot program|access-date=December 8, 2010|last = Paul|first = Ryan|date=December 2010| work=[[Ars Technica]]}}</ref>

The device's USB port is capable of supporting a keyboard, mouse, [[network interface controller|Ethernet adapter]], or USB storage, but not a printer, as ChromeOS offers no [[device driver|print stack]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.google.com/support/chromeos/bin/answer.py?answer=1069693 | title=Google Cloud Print Help | access-date=April 18, 2011}}</ref> Adding further hardware outside of the previously mentioned items will likely cause problems with the operating system's "self knowing" security model.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A9WVmNfgjtQ | archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211111/A9WVmNfgjtQ| archive-date=November 11, 2021 | url-status=live| title=YouTube – Chrome OS Security | website=[[YouTube]]| access-date=April 18, 2011}}{{cbignore}}</ref> Users instead were encouraged to use a secure service called [[Google Cloud Print]] to print to legacy printers connected to their desktop computers, or to connect an [[HP ePrint]], Kodak Hero, Kodak ESP, or Epson Connect printer to the Google Cloud Print service for a "cloud aware" printer connection.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.google.com/cloudprint/learn/printers.html#setup-hp#setup-kodak#setup-epson | title=Google Cloud Print | access-date=April 19, 2011}}</ref>

The Cr-48 prototype laptop gave reviewers their first opportunity to evaluate ChromeOS running on a device. Ryan Paul of ''[[Ars Technica]]'' wrote that the machine "met the basic requirements for Web surfing, gaming, and personal productivity, but falls short for more intensive tasks." He praised Google's approach to security but wondered whether mainstream computer users would accept an operating system whose only application is a browser. He thought ChromeOS "could appeal to some niche audiences": people who just need a browser or companies that rely on [[Google Apps]] and other [[Web applications]]. But the operating system was "decidedly not a full-fledged alternative to the general purpose computing environments that currently ship on netbooks." Paul wrote that most of ChromeOS's advantages "can be found in other software environments without having to sacrifice native applications."<ref name="Paul15Dec10" />

In reviewing the Cr-48 on December 29, 2010, Kurt Bakke of ''Conceivably Tech'' wrote that a Chromebook had become the most frequently used family appliance in his household. "Its 15 second startup time and dedicated Google user accounts made it the go-to device for quick searches, email as well as YouTube and Facebook activities." But the device did not replace other five notebooks in the house: one for gaming, two for the kids, and two more for general use. "The biggest complaint I heard was its lack of performance in Flash applications."<ref name="Bakke29Dec10">{{cite news|url = http://www.conceivablytech.com/4803/products/where-did-all-those-chromebooks-go-to/|title = Where Did All Those Chromebooks Go To?|access-date =December 30, 2010|last = Bakke|first = Kurt|date=December 2010| work=Conceivably Tech|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120202015354/http://www.conceivablytech.com/4803/products/where-did-all-those-chromebooks-go-to |archive-date = February 2, 2012}}</ref>

In ongoing testing, Wolfgang Gruener, also writing in ''Conceivably Tech'', said that cloud computing at cellular data speeds is unacceptable and that the lack of offline ability turns the Cr-48 "into a useless brick" when not connected.<ref name="Gruener18Jan11">{{cite news|url = http://www.conceivablytech.com/5243/products/when-google%E2%80%99s-cr-48-truly-sucks|title = When Google's Cr-48 Truly Sucks|access-date =March 2, 2011|last = Gruener|first = Wolfgang|date=January 2011| work=Conceivably Tech|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120418034631/http://www.conceivablytech.com/5243/products/when-google%E2%80%99s-cr-48-truly-sucks |archive-date = April 18, 2012}}</ref> "It's difficult to use the Chromebook as an everyday device and give up what you are used to on a Mac/Windows PC, while you surely enjoy the dedicated cloud computing capabilities occasionally."<ref name="Gruener27Feb11">{{cite news|url = http://www.conceivablytech.com/5863/business/cr-48-and-chrome-os-when-you-really-hate-netflix|title = Cr-48 and Chrome OS: When You Really Hate Netflix|access-date =March 2, 2011|last = Gruener|first = Wolfgang|date=February 2011| work=Conceivably Tech|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120110032430/http://www.conceivablytech.com/5863/business/cr-48-and-chrome-os-when-you-really-hate-netflix |archive-date = January 10, 2012}}</ref>

The Cr-48 features an Intel Atom N455, a single-core processor clocked at 1.66 GHz, with 512 KB of cache and hyperthreading enabled. It also features 2 GB of removable DDR3 memory in a single SO-DIMM, integrated chipset graphics (Intel GMA 3150), and a 66 watt-hour battery.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.notebookreview.com/notebookreview/google-cr-48-chrome-notebook-review/|title=Google Cr-48 Chrome Notebook Review {{!}} NotebookReview.com|work=NotebookReview.com|access-date=March 7, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> It has been found that the Intel NM10 chipset can get very hot during operation due to lack of a proper heatsink, but this has been fixed in production Chromebooks.{{Citation needed|date=March 2018}}

==== Samsung Series 5 ====
[[File:Samsung Chromebook.jpg|thumb|[[Samsung]] Series 5]]

Reviewing the Samsung Series 5 specifications, Scott Stein of [[CNET Networks|CNET]] was unimpressed with a machine with a 12-inch screen and just 16 GB of onboard storage. "Chrome OS might be lighter than Windows XP, but we'd still prefer more media storage space. At this price, you could also get an {{convert|11.6|in|mm|adj=on}} Wi-Fi AMD E-350-powered ultraportable running Windows 7."<ref name=CNET11May11>{{cite news|last=Stein|first=Scott|title=First Take: Samsung Series 5 Chromebook, the future of Netbooks?|url=http://news.cnet.com/first-take-samsung-series-5-chromebook-the-future-of-netbooks-hands-on-video/8301-17938_105-20061890-1.html|access-date=May 14, 2011|newspaper=CNET News|date=May 11, 2011}}</ref> On the other hand, MG Siegler of [[TechCrunch]] wrote a largely favorable review, praising the improvements in speed and touchpad sensitivity over the CR-48 prototype, as well as the long battery life and the fact that all models are priced below the iPad.<ref name="TechCrunchSamsung">{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/05/15/samsung-series-5-chromebook/ |title=Initial Thoughts on the Samsung Series 5 Chromebook |work=[[TechCrunch]] |date=May 16, 2011 }}</ref>

In June 2011, [[iFixit]] dismantled a Samsung Series 5 and concluded that it was essentially an improved Cr-48. They rated it as 6/10 for repairability, predominantly because the case has to be opened to change the battery and because the RAM chip is soldered to the motherboard. iFixit noted that the "mostly-plastic construction" felt "a little cheap". On the plus side they stated that the screen was easy to remove and most of the components, including the [[solid-state drive]] would be easy to replace. iFixit's Kyle Wiens wrote that the Series 5 "fixes the major shortfalls of the Cr-48 and adds the polish necessary to strike lust into the heart of a broad consumer base: sleek looks, 8+ hours of battery life, and optimized performance."<ref name="Paul10Jun11">{{cite news|url = https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/news/2011/06/ifixit-tears-the-chrome-off-of-a-samsung-chromebook.ars|title = iFixit tears the chrome off of a Samsung Chromebook|access-date = June 12, 2011|last = Paul|first = Ryan|date=June 2011| work = [[Ars Technica]]}}</ref>

==== Samsung Series 5 550 ====
In May 2012, Samsung introduced the Chromebook Series 5 550, with a Wi-Fi model and more expensive 3G model.<ref name="Samsung 2ndGen release">{{cite web|title=SAMSUNG And Google Introduce The Second-Generation Chromebook and The World's First Chromebox|url=http://www.samsung.com/us/news/presskitRead.do?news_seq=20179|publisher=Samsung press release|date=May 29, 2012|access-date=May 31, 2012}}</ref>

==== Samsung Series 3 ====
[[File:Samsung-Chromebook-box.jpg|thumb|Samsung Series 3 Chromebook]]

In October 2012, the Series 3 Chromebook was introduced at a San Francisco event with the Samsung Chromebook XE303. The device was cheaper, thinner and lighter than the Chromebook 550. Google marketed the Series 3 as the computer for everyone, due to its simple operating system (ChromeOS) and affordable price. Target markets included students and first-time computer users, as well as households looking for an extra computer.<ref name="CNET Series3 Review">{{cite news|title=Hands-on with Samsung's $249 Chromebook|url=https://www.cnet.com/laptops/samsung-chromebook-series-3/4505-3121_7-35500150.html|access-date=October 19, 2012|newspaper=CNET|date=October 18, 2012}}</ref><ref name="GoogleBlog Series 3">{{cite news|title=The new Chromebook, for everyone|url=http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2012/10/the-new-chromebook-for-everyone.html|access-date=October 19, 2012|newspaper=Google: Official Blog|date=October 18, 2012}}</ref>

The lower price proved a watershed for some reviewers. New York Times technology columnist [[David Pogue]] reversed his earlier thumbs-down verdict on the Chromebook, writing that "$250 changes everything." The price is half that of an "iPad, even less than an iPad Mini or an iPod Touch. And you’re getting a laptop." He wrote that the Chromebook does many of the things people use computers and laptops for: playing flash videos, and opening [[Microsoft Office]] documents. "In other words, Google is correct when it asserts that the Chromebook is perfect for schools, second computers in homes and businesses who deploy hundreds of machines."<ref name="Pogue Chromebook pt1">{{cite news|last=Pogue|first=David|title=A Laptop, Its Head in the Cloud|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/16/technology/personaltech/16pogue.html|access-date=November 30, 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=June 15, 2011 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140309072036/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/16/technology/personaltech/16pogue.html |archive-date = March 9, 2014|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Pogue:Chromebook pt2">{{cite news|last=Pogue|first=David|title=Laptop Buyers Should Pay Some Attention to the Chromebook|url=http://pogue.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/29/laptop-buyers-should-pay-some-attention-to-the-chromebook/|access-date=November 30, 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=November 29, 2012}}</ref>

[[CNET]]'s review of the Series 3 Chromebook was even more favorable, saying the machine largely delivered as a computer for students and as an additional computer for a household—especially for users who are already using Google Web applications like Google Docs, Google Drive, and Gmail. "It's got workable if not standout hardware, its battery life is good, it switches on quickly, and the $249 price tag means it's not as much of a commitment as the $550 Samsung Series 5 550 that arrived in May." The review subtracted points for performance. "It's fine for many tasks, but power users accustomed to having more than a couple dozen browser tabs open should steer clear."<ref name="CNET Series3 Review" />

== Desktop variants ==
Three types of [[desktop computer|desktop]] computers also run ChromeOS.

=== Chromebox ===
{{Main|Chromebox}}

Classed as [[Nettop|small form-factor PCs]], Chromeboxes typically feature a power switch and a set of ports: local area network, USB, DVI-D, [[DisplayPort]], and audio. As with Chromebooks, Chromeboxes employ solid-state memory and support Web applications, but require an external monitor, keyboard, and [[pointing device]].<ref name=ChromeboxDevice>{{cite web |url=https://www.google.com/intl/en/chrome/devices/chromebox.html |title=Chromebox device |access-date=May 29, 2012 |archive-date=March 16, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130316175358/https://www.google.com/intl/en/chrome/devices/chromebox.html |url-status=dead }}</ref>

=== Chromebit ===
{{main|Chromebit}}
The Chromebit is a [[stick PC]] running on Google's ChromeOS operating system. When placed in the HDMI port of a television or monitor, this device turns that display into a personal computer. Chromebit allows adding a keyboard and mouse over Bluetooth or USB port.

HDMI does not provide power to connected devices, so the Chromebit is supplied power from either an external USB power supply or draws power via a USB port on the monitor.

As of 2020, it no longer receives updates.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Auto Update policy - Chrome Enterprise and Education Help |url=https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/6220366?hl=en |access-date=2023-12-14 |website=support.google.com}}</ref>
